Dear SHANTHEIS MOODY:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
October 20, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
(3) The personnel record shall contain:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member’s
performance within a probationary period or not later
than 6 months after the staff member assumes his or
her current responsibilities. After the initial
evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
One of thirteen employee files reviewed did not contain written evaluations as
required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/19/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/16/2022
9/21/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/10/2021
CPA Rule 400.12214 Compliance with the child protection law
An agency shall comply with the child protection
law, 1975 PA 238, MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
Eight of thirteen employee files reviewed did not have documentation the agency
was in compliance with the child protection law.
2

CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall
have training in and maintain a current certification
in first aid from the American Heart Association or
the American Red Cross or other institution
approved by the department.
One of eight foster home files reviewed did not have current certification in CPR and
First Aid as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/19/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/16/2022
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation
within 45 calendar days after receipt of the
information. If additional time is required, then the
agency shall inform the foster parent, in writing, of
the basis for the extension and the expected length
of the extension. The total time for the completion of
the investigation shall not exceed 90 calendar days
without written approval from the chief administrator
or his or her designee.
One of four special investigations reviewed did not contain documentation the foster
parent was notified of the need for an extension and/or did not contain written
approval from the chief administrator the investigation exceeded 90 calendar days.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the
evaluation, an agency shall complete a written
report.
Two of four special investigations reviewed did not have a report completed within
15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
3

(1) Agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at
a minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as

(ii) A physical examination every 14 months.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have a physical examination

8/19/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/16/2022
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(a) Child's name.
(b) Child's date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child's
health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the
child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster
parent to provide a stable, safe, and healthy
environment for the foster child and the foster
family, including information about siblings who do
not reside in the foster home as provided in federal
law.
(i) Name of the assigned social service worker.
(j) Authorization to provide routine and emergency
m edical care.
Four of eight foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
information required within subsection a-j of this rule was provided to the caregivers
within the timeframes outlined within the rule.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/19/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/16/2022

FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned
change of placement or no later than three business
days after an unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting,
step-down from a residential or hospital setting,
return from AWOLP, or request for change in foster
home/relative placements.
Eight of eight foster care files reviewed and 3 of 3 independent living files
reviewed did not have FTM’s completed as required.

FOM 801-03 Medical passports
7

For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the child's
placement date to the following:
• Foster care provider.
• Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult re-entering foster care.
The actual date the medical passport is provided must
be documented in the electronic case management
record.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary
court ward.
Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
At reunification. Subsequent medical passports
are not required after reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider:
At or prior to each placement.
• All medical and mental health professionals to whom
the child is newly referred to and accepted for
treatment and/or services prior to or at the first
scheduled appointment while the foster care case is
open, regardless of placement. Subsequent medical
passports are not required.
• Older youth/young adults:
Upon initial independent living placement (youth
age 16 and over).
Upon exiting the foster care system (young
adults age 18 and older).
Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult:
8

Within two weeks of re-entry into voluntary
foster care.
Upon exiting voluntary foster care.
Eight of eight foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports and
required signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/19/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/16/2022
9/21/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/10/2021
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Annotate on signature line of PATP if it was mailed, emailed, reviewed,
etc.
• Upload Help Desk tickets if SOP was impacted.
• Special investigation checklist needs to be updated to include 45 day
and/or 90-day scenarios.
• FTM’s were conducted but focus should be to ensure they are able to be
considered timely.
• Orientation forms should be signed and dated by employee and
supervisor.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The facility did not request or require consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were 1 incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. A special evaluation was initiated on 12/19/2022 regarding allegations a
licensed foster parent was utilizing corporal punishment as discipline. The licensed
foster parent was found to be in violation of licensing rules and agency policy. A
CAP was approved on 4/21/2023 and continues to be implemented.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. SIR
9

2022C0212022 was initiated on 8/31/2022 regarding allegations the agency did
not open a special evaluation when they became aware of sleeping
arrangements/home concerns in a foster home. The agency sought a variance but
did not follow through with finalizing the variance. The investigation determined
violation of rule 400.12327 special evaluation and rule 400.12325 licensing
recommendation. A CAP was approved on 11/14/2022 and was completed.
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan in response to the
renewal inspection completed on 8/19/2022 with a corrective action plan approved
on 9/16/2022. During the review the agency had twenty violations. Eleven citations
were noted as repeat violations in the current inspection. During this period under
review the agency noted that overall compliance was impacted, in a part, by
increased staff turnover as well as increased placement issues.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment period reported the agency's difficulty in meeting requirements
during this review period. The Chief Administrator stated the previous year CAP
reflected a shift in processes and accountability for the agency. The CAP has
been, in part, successful, however increased staff turnover during the past year
has been challenging as well as a significant increase in placement issues.
The CA indicated the agency has implemented new initiatives to address areas of
non-compliance and allow for an extra layer of accountability. The CA expressed
confidence that several areas will improve over the next review period.
Financial Overview
Financial records were reviewed and there were no concerns identified.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Interviews were conducted with three staff via telephone. Staff report feeling
supported by the agency. Supervisors are available and coworkers assist as
needed. Staff did not report any concerns or areas of need.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care, licensing and adoption services. All files were stored
securely.
10

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Agency Analyst identified one safety concern as follows:
Safety Alert: Licensed relative foster parent did not comply with Agency Analyst's
multiple requests to conduct a home visit.
Resolution: Agency completed a special investigation based on rule 400.9206 Foster
home evaluation. A CAP is currently in place.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
